Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The United States has significant vulnerabilities with respect to Information Assurance (IA). US colleges and universities need to increase the number of qualified professionals to help respond to this threat. This project supports travel for seven US educators and other Information Assurance (IA) experts to attend a working group meeting in Ankara, Turkey. The focus of the working group is to examine key governmental and industry IA education standards and the curricula of existing academic programs. An expected outcome is a report that defines the IA education space along with specific curricular recommendations for a selected topic. This effort is the initial step to developing comprehensive IA curricular recommendations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If the US colleges and universities are to produce more Information Assurance (IA) graduates, more of them need to create IA programs. If they are to create IA programs, they need guidance as to what those programs should include. This project covered the travel expenses for six faculty at US institutions to travel to ITiCSE 2010 to work in a working group dedicated to IA education. This IA working group produced a report:

Stephen Cooper, Christine Nickell, Lance C. Pérez, Brenda Oldfield, Joel Brynielsson, As?m Gencer Gökce, Elizabeth K. Hawthorne, Karl J. Klee, Andrea Lawrence, and Susanne Wetzel. 2010. Towards information assurance (IA) curricular guidelines. In Proceedings of the 2010 ITiCSE working group reports on Working group reports (ITiCSE-WGR '10), Alison Clear and Lori Russell Dag (Eds.). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 49-64. DOI=10.1145/1971681.1971686 http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/1971681.1971686

This report proposes a set of curricular guidelines. It is important that the guidelines were to be developed by a collection of IA education experts, with feedback from leading government IA professionals, and further input from IA educators from other countries.

The current CNSS standards, the 401x series that defines the necessary mapping for IA program, are nearly 20 years old, and are closer to training standards than they are to educational standards/guidelines. NSA (the federal agency that accredits Centers for Academic Excellence in IA education and research at both the two-year and four-year school levels, in conjunction with DHS) is comfortable with this proposed effort to develop a newer and more “academic” approach towards curricular guidelines, and many universities will be able to use the new guidelines to develop their own IA programs. The threat of not increasing the number of IA graduates (at all levels) to react to today’s and tomorrow’s IA challenges in government and industry is too frightening to even consider.
